fields.Video Description: This video was recorded by Richard Benton in Minneapolis, USA, where he and James, a pastor, met. Nur, also written as Nuer, is spoken by as many as 900,000 people, primarily in the Central African nations of Ethiopia, in particular the Gambela region, and South Sudan. Along with the Dinka language, it is one of Central-Eastern Africa‚Äôs most widely spoken mother tongues. It is written with a variety of the Latin alphabet, and is dialectically diverse, with at least 15 distinct varieties. A Nilo-Saharan language, Nur is perhaps most similar to the Jieng variety of Dinka and the Shilluk language of South and North Sudan, also known as Chollo.
Demographics: 740,000 in South Sudan (1982). 2,940 Western Jikany, 12,500 Lou, 1,100 Nyuong, 2,500 Thiang, 5,900 Bul, 2,400 Jagai, 6,700 Laak, 4,900 Leik, 1,600 Door, 17,600 Eastern Jikany (Voegelin and Voegelin 1977). Population total all countries: 891,000.
YouTube License Statement: This video is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International license. To download a copy, please contact hello@wikitongues.org.
fields.Geneaology: "[ Nilo-Saharan, Eastern Sudanic, Nilotic, Western, Dinka-Nuer, Nuer ]"
